sentences.sentence: By Paige MacPherson and Michael ZwaagstraIt's time to rethink the "progressive" teaching trends that have taken over Canadian classrooms in recent decades and have coincided with a sharp decline in student math and reading performance.According to new results from the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA(https://www.oecd.org/publication/pisa-2022-results/)) - a standardized test of 15-year-olds around the globe in reading, science and math - Canadian math scores have declined precipitously over the last 20 years.
Between 2003 and 2022, they fell from 532 to 497, a steeper decline than the OECD average (500 to 472).
One in five Canadian students is performing at the lowest level in math, and Canadian-born students are performing less well than their immigrant peers.

All credit to new Canadians but the declining performance of young people born here should be a concern.Although 78 per cent of Canadian 15-year-olds are at or above a baseline of math proficiency, Canada's downward trend over time is troubling.
Baseline here refers to "Level 2" proficiency - there are six levels of proficiency.

The director for education and skills at the OECD (which created PISA testing) says Canadian student results are a cause for concern, as the changing world requires strong math skills now more than ever.School closures and other COVID policies clearly caused learning disruptions and hurt student achievement over the last couple of years.
But Canada's downward trend in math performance precedes the pandemic.

Math scores have been falling here since 2003.If we don't offer students the building blocks in math - clear, direct instruction from teachers - they'll have trouble moving on to more complex problems.
Just as a pianist must practice scales before attempting a Beethoven sonata, students must commit basic math facts to memory before trying to solve advanced algebraic equations.

They need to memorize(https://www.cdhowe.org/sites/default/files/attachments/research_papers/mixed/commentary_427.pdf) basic math facts, such as multiplication tables, and learn the standard algorithms for addition, subtraction, multiplication and division.The latest PISA scores are a warning for other subjects, too.
Canadian students are also performing more poorly in reading.
This comes as little surprise.

The science of reading shows that phonics instruction is vastly superior(https://www.ohrc.on.ca/sites/default/files/FINAL%20R2R%20REPORT%20DESIGNED%20April%2012.pdf) to the now more widely used but ineffective "three-cueing" approach, in which students guess the meaning of unfamiliar words based on context.
If we don't teach students phonics, many will never be able to decode words and read with confidence.

They need to learn how to sound out individual letters and phrases, which requires a good deal of focused instruction by competent classroom teachers.Research also shows that students benefit(https://education.virginia.edu/news-stories/study-knowledge-rich-curriculum-significantly-boosts-reading-scores) from knowledge-rich classroom environments.
For example, there's a strong causal relationship between background knowledge and reading comprehension.

This means teachers should do everything they can to help students acquire subject-specific facts.Finally, if students don't know key names and dates in history class, they can't contextualize important historical events and think critically about their implications today.

For example, no one can give an informed opinion about whether schools and other buildings should be named after Sir John A. Macdonald without knowing basic facts about his life and the times during which he served as prime minister.We need to reject, once and for all, the notion that "inquiry learning" is the best way for students to learn.
Teachers should reclaim their proper role as subject-matter experts who take charge of learning.

Most students do not benefit when teachers are mere guides on the side to be consulted from time to time as they teach themselves.Independent schools help parents who feel left out(https://financialpost.com/opinion/independent-schools-help-parents-left-out-public-boards)Here's how to help kids catch up from COVID closures(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-closing-schools-during-covid-set-kids-back-heres-how-they-can-catch-up)Ensure all kids can read to help increase productivity(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-one-way-to-increase-productivity-ensure-all-kids-can-read)If we want to reverse Canada's long-term academic decline, we need to improve the quality of instruction in schools.

Otherwise, we'll be disappointed by the next round of PISA results, too, and continue to shortchange our students and limit their ability to achieve their full potential after graduation.Paige MacPherson is associate director of education policy studies at the Fraser Institute, where Michael Zwaagstra is a senior fellow.
